awd_titl_txt: Probing the molecular interactions at the extrahaustorial membrane interface
awd_abstract_narration:
Food security is a grand challenge facing humanity in the face of climate change and population growth; yet, on a global scale up to 15% of crops are lost to pathogens each year. Protecting crops from pathogens is a critical, ongoing global initiative. Many agriculturally important diseases are caused by powdery mildew and rust fungi, and fungus-like oomycete pathogens. One common feature of these evolutionarily distinct pathogens is that they develop similar feeding structures called haustoria to invade plants and extract nutrients from host cells. Despite tremendous progress towards understanding the molecular mechanisms of plant resistance against pathogens, how the host defense is executed in the plant-haustorial interface is still poorly characterized. The research aims to identify and functionally characterize novel molecular players at the host-pathogen interface termed the extrahaustorial membrane using a model pathosystem and state-of-the-art genetics and biochemistry tools. New findings from this project will not only lead to a better understanding of the molecular composition of the host-pathogen interface but also help design novel strategies to fight against haustorium-forming pathogens and reduce crop losses, thereby contributing to sustainable agriculture. 

Haustorium-forming pathogens such as powdery mildew fungi develop a feeding structure termed the haustorium in host tissues to secrete effector proteins capable of suppressing the host immune response and extracting nutrients from the host cell. The haustorium is physically separated from the host cell by a host-derived interfacial membrane named the extrahaustorial membrane (EHM). The EHM is believed to be the most critical host-pathogen battleground, where the host defense is mounted to constrain the haustorium, and the pathogen deploys effectors to subvert host immunity and extracts nutrients from the host. However, despite the importance of the EHM, its molecular components and the mechanisms associated with host defense or pathogenesis are poorly characterized. The long term goal of this project is to understand the protein composition of the EHM and the mechanisms of plant-haustorium interactions at this host-pathogen interface. Using the Arabidopsis-powdery mildew interaction as a model pathosystem and RPW8.2 (a broad-spectrum resistance protein) as the first and best EHM-specific resident protein, a collaborative team will (i) identify and characterize proteins interacting with RPW8.2 at the EHM and additional EHM-resident proteins via proximity-based labeling coupled with enrichment/purification of haustorial complexes followed by mass spectrometry; (ii) resolve the protein structure of RPW8.2 and understand how EHM-oriented vesicle transport of RPW8.2 is regulated by a candidate SNARE complex at the Trans-Golgi Network; and (iii) identify host susceptibility factors, such as sugar transporters, which may be recruited to the EHM by powdery mildew fungi for nutrient acquisition through both genetic and cell biological approaches.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project (IOS-1901566) builds on previous research that identified the specific localization of RPW8.2, a plant resistance protein, at the extra-haustorial membrane (EHM) which separates the host cell from the fungal feeding structure, the haustorium. The long-term goal of this project is to enhance our understanding of how biotrophic fungi, such as powdery mildew, manipulate host cellular processes to facilitate infection and how plants mount effective defense responses at the host-pathogen interface, i.e., the EHM.  Using the Arabidopsis-powdery mildew pathosystem, the project targets three specific objectives: (1) Identify and characterize additional EHM-resident proteins through proteomics; (2) Elucidate RPW8-mediated, EHM-based defense mechanisms; (3) Identify host susceptibility factors contributing to powdery mildew pathogenesis. The overarching objective is to understand the molecular interactions occurring at the EHM.

Through a combination of advanced techniques, particularly RPW8.2-TurboID proximity labeling, this project identified several potential EHM-localized proteins. These include plant-specific Rab5-like proteins (Ara6, Ara7, and RhaI), two putative fungal RNase-like effector proteins, and a sugar transporter (STP8) (New Phytologist 230: 2404-2419; DOI: 10.1111/nph.17347; manuscripts in preparation).

Genetic and molecular studies revealed that RPW8.2 undergoes vacuole-dependent degradation in naïve cells but is specifically redirected to the EHM in haustorium-invaded cells through transient reorientation of vacuolar trafficking. Mutations in the Qb-SNARE VTI11 significantly impaired RPW8.2 localization to the EHM, indicating that RPW8.2-vesicle trafficking is regulated by a VTI11-containing SNARE complex and possibly Rab5-like GTPases (manuscript in preparation).

Further analyses demonstrated that RPW8.2 interacts with and depends on the RPW8 domain-containing helper nucleotide-binding leucine-rich-repeat (NLR) proteins ADR1, ADR1-L1, and ADR1-L2 for function. RPW8.2 may act as a sorting adaptor, facilitating ADR1 oligomerization and/or anchoring ADR1 to EHM-directed vesicles in haustorium-invaded cells, thereby enhancing resistance to powdery mildew (manuscript in preparation).

To uncover host proteins or processes exploited by powdery mildew, a large-scale genetic screen was performed in the eds1-pad4-sid2 triple mutant background, aiming at identifying mutants with compromised immunity but poor infection (cipi). Among eight causal cipi mutations, MLO2 and three other genes emerged as potential susceptibility factors. Further genetic studies revealed that “complete resistance” in the eds1-pad4-sid2-mlo2-mlo6-mlo12 sextuple mutant background can occur without defense activation, demonstrating MLO2, MLO6, and MLO12 as bona fide susceptibility factors essential for powdery mildew pathogenesis (manuscript in preparation).

Collectively, this project has significantly advanced our understanding of molecular interactions between Arabidopsis and powdery mildew. Additionally, the project elucidated the genetic mechanism underlying leaf abaxial immunity to powdery mildew (Journal of Experimental Botany 75: 1465-1478; DOI: 10.1093/jxb/erad450) and developed a simple, effective powdery mildew inoculation method (Journal of Visualized Experiments; DOI: 10.3791/62287).

The project also laid the foundation for a collaborative NSF Plant Genome Research Program project on the genetic basis of nonhost resistance (Molecular Plant Pathology 24: 272-283; DOI: 10.1111/mpp.13290) and fostered productive collaborations, resulting in over 10 additional publications.

The broader impacts of this project have been substantial, fostering advancements in research, education, and collaboration. One notable outcome is the successful collection, identification, purification, and long-term maintenance of eight powdery mildew species at the PI’s institute. This resource has provided unique opportunities for the PI and seven additional laboratories, both within and outside the United States, to investigate plant immunity mechanisms against host-adapted and non-adapted powdery mildew species in diverse contexts. For instance, in collaboration with the University of Florida, the Arabidopsis powdery mildew isolate Golovinomyces cichoracearum UCSC1 and the eds1-pad4-sid2 mutant were supplied to facilitate studies on plant defense and powdery mildew pathogenesis in space. Additionally, three higher-order Arabidopsis mutants, eds1-pad4-sid2, eds1-pad4-sid2-pld𝛿 and eds1-pad4-sid2-pen1-pen2-pen3, generated through this project, have been deposited in the Arabidopsis Biological Resource Center (ABRC) to ensure their dissemination to the broader research community.

The project’s findings have been integrated into educational settings as well. The infection of the eds1-pad4-sid2 triple mutant by the non-adapted sow thistle powdery mildew is now featured as a practical lab module, “Seeing is Believing,” in the core undergraduate course Principles of Plant Pathology at the University of Maryland College Park. This hands-on component enhances student understanding of plant-pathogen interactions and nonhost resistance through direct observation.

In terms of workforce development, the project supported the training of four postdoctoral researchers (for durations ranging from six months to two years), three graduate students (two PhD and one MSc), six undergraduate students, and one high school intern. Notably, more than half of the trainees were from underrepresented groups (female and/or URM), contributing to the diversification of the STEM pipeline.

This project has significantly advanced research on host-pathogen interactions at the EHM interface and catalyzed two new lines of scientific quests: the genetic basis of nonhost resistance in plants and the molecular role of MLO proteins as host susceptibility factors. The foundational knowledge and resources generated continue to drive innovation and collaboration in plant-pathogen biology.
